Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Cost of Failure: Gender and Risk-taking Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cecilia Ridgeway
Susan Fisk
Stanford University

The researchers study whether women face greater social and employment penalties for unsuccessful risk-taking behavior than otherwise similar men, which may provide some insight as to why women generally take fewer risks than men. The study pairs two interrelated experiments to test whether women receive greater sanctions for unsuccessful risk-taking behavior than otherwise similar men. The first experiment has been completed, and found that women who made riskier bets on their own performance were less likely to be picked as a research study partner than otherwise identical men. The second study examines the economic and employment consequences of unsuccessful risk-taking for women and men. Non-profit lenders and high-tech workers will evaluate fictitious profiles of women and men in the workplace. These profiles include examples of unsuccessful risk-taking behavior: for instance, starting a business that failed after a year, or introducing a new initiative at a corporation that had the potential to be very profitable, but which ended up losing money. The goal is to see whether women are viewed as less hirable, competent, fundable, and likeable than otherwise identical men if they have taken an unsuccessful risk.

Broader Impacts

This research has implications for gender inequality, as risk-taking behavior is powerfully tied to resources, power, and status. Indeed, one often has to take a risk to reap a reward. It is likely that women engage in fewer risk-taking endeavors if they face greater penalties then men, whether through decreased employment prospects, lessened funding opportunities, or dislike by others. If this is true many of the individuals with the most status, power and resources in society (e.g. successful businesspersons, entrepreneurs, investors, and politicians) took risks to achieve their current positions. Sanctions against women for risk-taking may effectively limit the opportunities they have to acquire these valued resources. Beyond increasing gender inequality, this phenomenon may be decreasing economic efficiency. If talented women take fewer risks due to fear of sanctioning, society may have fewer innovative ideas and products, businesses that create jobs, and effective leaders. Conversely, if men face fewer sanctions, it may encourage some men to engage in high-risk, high-reward behavior that leads to ruin for themselves or others (e.g. the recent financial crisis). Awareness of this phenomenon could potentially allow institutions to improve their decision-making processes to increase efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines whether women and men face different consequences, in terms of employment outcomes and social sanctions, when they engage in risk-taking behavior. In particular, the project explores the effect that both successful and unsuccessful risk-taking behavior has on evaluations and whether there are gender differences in the magnitude of these effects.

I find evidence that women have more to lose than men when they take risks and fail. While I do not find evidence that this bias is evenly distributed in the population, I do find evidence that individuals who identify as conservative — and who likely have more traditional gender beliefs — are more likely to state that women who take risks and fail will receive greater workplace penalties than otherwise similar men. These penalties include an increased likelihood of being downsized, poorer odds of promotion, less pay and bonus, and decreased odds of being sent to leadership training. I do not find any evidence that women have less to gain than otherwise similar men when they take successful risks nor when the outcome of their risk-taking behavior is unknown.

Even though the bias is not evenly distributed among all members of the population, it is worth nothing that many individuals in the sample (27% to be exact) identified as conservative, which is an even smaller percent than the 38% of Americans who identify as conservative in national polls (Gallup 2015). Even if the majority of individuals do not penalize women more for failure, women still have more to lose if they take risks, given that 2 in 5 individuals will likely penalize them for failure to a greater extent than an otherwise similar man. This is especially the case given that wealthier individuals are both more likely to be conservative and to make consequential workplace evaluations, such as hiring, firing, and promotion decisions (Brooks and Brady 1999; Gelman et al. 2005).

This project helps elucidates a mechanism that may be perpetuating gender inequality, as risk-taking behavior is powerfully tied to the distribution of society's rewards: one must often take a risk in order to reap a reward. If women face greater penalties for failure in risk-taking domains, this may cause them to take fewer chances, curtailing their share of wealth, status, and power. Conversely, the relative lack of sanctions may cause some men to take too many risks, leading to ruin for themselves and others.
